base_prompt.S: Curate a playlist of trip hop tracks.

prompt.S: Lean into the classic 90s Bristol sound: smoky downtempo beats, vinyl crackle, moody basslines, and noir atmosphere. Prioritise era-defining staples plus deep cuts; avoid big-beat and EDM crossover.
Cinematic noir lounge: late-night bar mood, brushed drums, upright bass, sleazy jazz chords, and whispered vocals. Keep it classy and slow-burn; avoid anything too bright or poppy.
Jazz-inflected trip hop: dusty jazz samples, Rhodes keys, sax motifs, and head-nod drums. Keep it warm and organic; mix instrumentals with vocal tracks.
Soundtrack-like trip hop: suspenseful strings/pads, tight percussion, and dramatic builds. Aim for spy-thriller energy without going industrial or overly aggressive.
Dubby downtempo trip hop: deep sub-bass, skanks/echo, spacey delays, and slow breakbeats. Keep it hypnotic and mellow; avoid fast DnB sections.
Vocal-forward trip hop: intimate, breathy, emotionally present vocals over minimal beats and moody harmony. Keep it sensual and restrained; avoid mainstream pop ballad vibes.
Leftfield trip hop: experimental textures, odd samples, and unconventional arrangementsâ€”still listenable and groove-led. Avoid harsh noise, extreme industrial, or chaotic breakcore.
Rain-soaked neon city atmosphere: airy pads, distant synths, echoing snares, and late-night melancholy. Keep tempos downtempo; favour immersive sound design.
Tape-hazy trip hop: mellow breaks, soft saturation, hiss, and nostalgic samples. Keep it cosy and unhurried; avoid modern EDM loudness.
Psychedelic downtempo adjacent to trip hop: woozy synths, swirling effects, hypnotic grooves, and spacious mixes. Keep it chill; avoid full psytrance or four-on-the-floor club energy.
